title: Switch
description: Switches toggle the state of a single item on or off.

contentChunks.htmlValue: There's one type of switch in Material. Use this selection control when the user needs to toggle a single item on or off.
Resources

TypeLinkStatus
DesignDesign kit (Figma)Available
M2 guideline – SwitchAvailable
ImplementationMDC-AndroidAvailable
Jetpack ComposeAvailable
FlutterIn progress
WebPlanned
Takeaways

• Switches have been in user interfaces for a long time and should be used as expected. A switch’s state should be visible at a glance.
  • Selected items should be more visually prominent than unselected items
  • Switches make it easy to compare available options
What's new

• Accessibility: Visual presentation is more accessible
  • Color: New color mappings meet non-text-contrast requirements in addition to compatibility with dynamic color
  • Icons: Ability to have an optional icon within the switch thumb
  • Layout: Track is taller and wider

contentChunks.footer: M2: Switches have circular thumb that extends beyond the edge of the track.
contentChunks.altText: alt text: Side-by-side switch icons in on and off mode

contentChunks.footer: M3: Switches have a taller and wider track, new color mappings, and the ability to hold an icon in the switch thumb.
contentChunks.altText: alt text: Side-by-side switches showing color, track, and switch thumb icon.

Color

Color values are implemented through design tokens. For design, this means working with color values that correspond with tokens. For implementation, a color value will be a token that references a value. Learn more about design tokens.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Contents

Usage
Anatomy
Placement
Behavior

contentChunks.altText: 3 example cards with headlines and body text

contentChunks.htmlValue: Usage
Switches are the preferred way to adjust settings. They're used to control binary options – think On/Off or True/False.

contentChunks.footer: Use a switch to turn an option on and off

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Use switches to:

  • Toggle a single item on or off
  • Immediately activate or deactivate something

contentChunks.footer: Use switches to turn states on or off, specifically on mobile instead of a checkbox
contentChunks.altText: alt text: Mobile device screen showing 'on' mode switch.

contentChunks.htmlValue: Switches should be used instead of radio buttons if each item in a set can be independently controlled.

contentChunks.footer: Use radio buttons to toggle items on or off. Radio buttons convey that a set of items are options and can only be selected one at a time. Instead use switches.
contentChunks.altText: alt text: Device screen showing two stacked radio buttons.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Switches control binary options, not opposing ones. A binary option represents a single state that is either on or off. 

Opposing options are two separate states that are opposite but related to different user tasks.

contentChunks.footer: Don’t use switches to control opposing options. Instead, use a different component like a segmented button.
contentChunks.altText: alt text: Example of selected switch placed between text.

contentChunks.footer: Use segmented buttons to control opposing options
contentChunks.altText: alt text: Segmented text button with selected, unselected text.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Alternate selection controls

Checkboxes and radio buttons are alternative selection controls that can be used to enter decisions or declare preferences such as settings or dialogs.

contentChunks.footer: Checkboxes
contentChunks.altText: alt text: Side-by-side boxes, empty box on left,  checked box on right.

contentChunks.footer: Radio buttons
contentChunks.altText: alt text: Side-by-side radio buttons with filled button on left, empty button on right.

contentChunks.footer: Use checkboxes (not switches) to let users select one or more options from a list.
contentChunks.altText: alt text: Screen showing stacked checkboxes on left, button on lower right.

contentChunks.footer: Don’t use a switch in place of a button. When users see a call to action, they expect to interact with a button, not a switch.
contentChunks.altText: alt text: Screen showing stacked checkboxes on left, selected switch on lower right.

contentChunks.footer: Use radio buttons (not switches) when only one item can be selected from a list.
contentChunks.altText: alt text: Screen showing three stacked radio buttons, with one selected.

contentChunks.footer: Don’t use a switch to select one or more options from a list. Switches should provide an immediate noticeable effect that doesn’t require the user to click Save or Submit to apply the new state.
contentChunks.altText: alt text: Screen showing text on left, corresponding selected and unselected switches on right.

contentChunks.htmlValue: Anatomy

contentChunks.footer:
1. Track
2. Thumb
3. Icon (optional)
contentChunks.altText: alt text: Diagram of switch anatomy.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Icon (optional)

The switch thumb can contain an optional icon.

contentChunks.footer: The icon within the thumb should always communicate the state of the switch.

contentChunks.htmlValue: Icons can be used to visually emphasize the switch’s selected state. The icon’s meaning should be clear and unambiguous to help the user understand whether switch is on or off.

contentChunks.footer: Use icons that clearly communicate whether the switch is on or off, such as an X and a checkmark.
contentChunks.altText: alt text: Four switches with icons in various on/off modes.

contentChunks.footer: Use caution when incorporating icons that have more ambiguous or non-binary meanings, such as moon and edit.
contentChunks.altText: alt text: Two switches containing hard-to-decipher icons.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Label text

Switches should always be paired with an inline label describing the option that the switch controls, as well as its state.

contentChunks.footer: Keep labels short and direct. A label should describe what the control does when the switch is on.
contentChunks.altText: alt text: Screen showing stacked inline labels and switch controls.

contentChunks.footer: Don't add label text into the switch itself because the small font size can be difficult to read. Instead, use icons in the thumb to communicate selection state.
contentChunks.altText: alt text: Screen showing stacked inline labels and switch controls containing label text.

contentChunks.htmlValue: Placement
Switches are often arranged in stacked layouts.

contentChunks.footer: Settings screens are common places to use switches.
contentChunks.altText: alt text: Screen showing labels and stacked switches in varying on/off modes.

contentChunks.htmlValue: Behavior
A switch is successfully toggled when the switch thumb slides to the other side of the track upon user interaction.

contentChunks.footer: Upon selection, the switch thumb slides to the opposite end of the track.
contentChunks.altText: alt text: Selected switch handle slid to track end.

contentChunks.htmlValue: When a user toggles a switch, its thumb size changes and the corresponding action takes effect immediately.

contentChunks.footer: The "on" state of the switch is indicated by a larger thumb size.
contentChunks.altText: alt text: Switch with chechmark icon set to 'on' mode.

contentChunks.htmlValue: Use cases

Users should be able to:

  • Navigate to a switch with keyboard/switch input
  • Toggle the switch on and off
  • Get appropriate feedback based on input type documented under Behavior & style
Behavior & style

The switch thumb increases in size to indicate interactivity for both touch and cursor control interactions.

Touch
When tapped or dragged, the handle size grows, providing feedback to the user that the thumb is being interacted.

Cursor
When hovered or clicked (in both on and off states), the handle size grows, providing a visual cue to the user that the thumb is interactive.

contentChunks.footer: Touch: Tap, Drag.
contentChunks.altText: alt text: Diagram of switch handle enlarging when tapped or or dragged.

contentChunks.footer: Cursor: Hover, Click
contentChunks.altText: alt text: Diagram of switch handle transitioning from inactive to hover to click.

contentChunks.htmlValue: Initial focus
Initial focus lands directly on the switch’s thumb, since it’s the primary interactive element of the component.

contentChunks.footer: Focus lands on the switch thumb
contentChunks.altText: alt text: Diagram of activated switch handle above tab.

contentChunks.footer: The switch is toggled via Space/Enter
contentChunks.altText: alt text: Diagram of switch handle above tab on left, switch handle placed space/enter tab on right.

contentChunks.htmlValue: Keyboard navigation

KeysActions
TabFocus lands on the switch thumb
Space / EnterToggles the thumb between on and off states
Labeling elements

The accessibility label for a switch is typically the same as the switch’s adjacent text label.

If the UI text is correctly linked to the switch, assistive tech (such as a screenreader) will read the UI text followed by the component’s role.

contentChunks.footer: A switch’s accessibility label can incorporate its adjacent UI text.
contentChunks.altText: alt text: Device screen showing highlighted text label and accessibility label with same text.

contentChunks.htmlValue: Some accessibility labels require more descriptive text, particularly when the visible UI text is ambiguous. For example, a switch visibly labelled “Photo album” would benefit from additional information in its accessibility label to clarify the switch’s function.

contentChunks.footer: While the visible label text reads “Photo album,” the accessibility label for this switch clarifies its function: “Photo album access.”
contentChunks.altText: alt text: Device screen showing highlighted text label and accessibility label with more descriptive text.

contentChunks.htmlValue: Resources

• Accessibility research/key considerations for Switches on/off patterns
  • Link to any other components that contain compatible information or patterns
